concepts.sumo_definition:
The process of ensuring
an &%ArtificialIntelligence's goals and behaviors align with human values
and intentions.
concepts.definition: The process of ensuring an artificial intelligence system's goals, behaviors, and decision-making align with human values, ethics, and intentions. This process involves techniques and methods to prevent AI systems from pursuing objectives that are misaligned with or harmful to human interests.

concepts.sumo_definition:
Any engineered artifact that implements, embodies, or supports
   artificial intelligence capabilities, including models, datasets,
   training runs, and harness components.
concepts.definition: An engineered artifact that implements, embodies, or supports artificial intelligence capabilities, including machine learning models, training datasets, computational training runs, and supporting infrastructure components.

concepts.sumo_definition:
The systems, rules, and processes
for overseeing the development, deployment, and use of &%ArtificialIntelligence
to ensure safety and beneficial outcomes.
concepts.definition: a mistake resulting from inattention

concepts.sumo_definition:
The process of an
&%ArtificialIntelligence expanding its capabilities, knowledge, or
effectiveness through learning, training, or self-improvement.
concepts.definition: act of improving by expanding or enlarging or refining

concepts.sumo_definition:
Any &%AnatomicalStructure
which is not normally found in the &%Organism of which it is a part, i.e. it is
the result of a &%PathologicProcess.  This class covers tumors, birth marks,
goiters, etc.
concepts.definition: hermaphroditic gonad that contains both testicular and ovarian tissue

concepts.sumo_definition:
&%AirPollution is the subclass of
&%Pollution processes in which air is contaminated.
concepts.definition: pollution of the atmosphere

concepts.sumo_definition: An airline alliance is an agreement between two or more airlines to cooperate on a substantial level.
concepts.definition: An airline alliance is an agreement between two or more airlines to cooperate on a substantial level.

concepts.sumo_definition:
An &%Organism with eukaryotic &%Cells, and lacking
stiff cell walls, plastids, and photosynthetic pigments.
concepts.definition: a living organism characterized by voluntary movement

concepts.sumo_definition:
&%AnatomicalStructures that
are possessed exclusively by &%Animals.
concepts.definition: A structural component or part of an animal's body that is exclusive to members of the animal kingdom, such as organs, tissues, or body parts not found in plants or other organisms.

concepts.sumo_definition:
An internal or external representation of an AISystem's structure,
   including layers, components, and interconnections (e.g. a graph of
   modules, a schema, or textual description).
concepts.definition: A formal depiction or model of an artificial intelligence system's structural organization, documenting its constituent elements such as layers, modules, components, and their interconnections through various formats including diagrams, schemas, or textual descriptions.

concepts.sumo_definition:
&%AreaOfConcern is a subclass of
&%Attributes that represent and classify the kinds of interests that
agents have.
concepts.definition: A category of interest or attention that represents the kinds of subjects, topics, or domains that engage an agent's focus or consideration. This attribute classifies the scope of what an entity regards as relevant or important.

concepts.sumo_definition: Propositions that present reasoning, explanations, or persuasive claims to support or establish a point of view.
concepts.definition: Propositions that present reasoning, explanations, or persuasive claims to support or establish a point of view.

positive_examples: The defense attorney's closing argument emphasized reasonable doubt based on inconsistent witness testimony.
Her hypothesis that increased screen time causes sleep disorders was supported by multiple studies.
The politician used rhetorical questions and emotional appeals to convince voters of his economic plan.
Scientists proposed that climate change explains the recent pattern of extreme weather events.
The debate team's argument connected historical precedents to justify their policy recommendation.
His persuasive essay used logical reasoning and evidence to argue for renewable energy investment.
negative_examples: The mathematical theorem states that the sum of angles in a triangle equals 180 degrees.
Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius at sea level pressure.
The company's financial statement showed a 15% increase in quarterly profits.
The recipe calls for two cups of flour and one cup of sugar.
The dictionary defines 'democracy' as government by the people.
The map indicates that the library is located three blocks north of the school.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: FactualStatement, Definition, Instruction, Query, Assumption

concepts.sumo_definition: Relations classified by the specific number of entities they connect or relate together
concepts.definition: Relations classified by the specific number of entities they connect or relate together

positive_examples: Marriage is a binary relation between two people
The function f(x,y,z) defines a ternary relation among three variables
A quaternary predicate relates exactly four distinct arguments
This quintary operation requires five input parameters
Variable arity functions can take any number of arguments
The relation's arity determines how many entities it can connect
negative_examples: The similarity between cats and dogs is strong
John has a meaningful relationship with his sister
These two concepts are closely related in meaning
The connection between cause and effect is important
All mammals share common characteristics
The association between smoking and cancer is well-established
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: SpatialRelation, TemporalRelation, CausalRelation, EquivalenceRelation

concepts.definition: Grouping category for ATMSlot, Crankcase, GolfHole...

concepts.sumo_definition:
An Attribute describing characteristic patterns of offensive behavior
   (e.g. injection, exfiltration, privilege escalation, worm-like
   replication).
concepts.definition: A characteristic mode or method of offensive behavior in information systems, describing the techniques and strategies used in cyber attacks such as code injection, data exfiltration, privilege escalation, or malware propagation.

concepts.sumo_definition: Cognitive mechanisms that direct, focus, or allocate mental resources and processing capacity.
concepts.definition: Cognitive mechanisms that direct, focus, or allocate mental resources and processing capacity.

positive_examples: She focused intently on the speaker's words, blocking out background noise.
The driver quickly scanned the intersection for oncoming traffic before turning.
He concentrated deeply on solving the complex math problem step by step.
The student's mind wandered during the lecture despite trying to pay attention.
She automatically noticed the red warning light flashing on the dashboard.
The detective carefully examined each piece of evidence for important clues.
negative_examples: She remembered her childhood address after years of forgetting it.
He learned to ride a bicycle through practice and repetition.
The scientist formed a hypothesis about the experimental results.
She felt happy when she received the good news.
He stored the phone number in his mental notebook for later use.
The child recognized her mother's face in the crowd.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Memory, Learning, Reasoning, Perception, EmotionalProcess

concepts.sumo_definition:
An automated system is
the &%agent of an &%AutomatedProcess. 'Automated' simply means that
actions can be carried out by something other than a
&%CognitiveAgent.
concepts.definition: A system that acts as an agent in automated processes, capable of carrying out actions without the direct involvement of a cognitive agent such as a human. The system performs operations independently through mechanical, electronic, or computational means.

concepts.sumo_definition: Cognitive processes that systematically favor or disadvantage groups through stereotypes, discrimination, or selective perception.
concepts.definition: Cognitive processes that systematically favor or disadvantage groups through stereotypes, discrimination, or selective perception.

positive_examples: The hiring manager unconsciously favored candidates from elite universities over equally qualified applicants.
She automatically assumed the Asian student would be good at math without knowing their actual abilities.
The algorithm systematically rejected loan applications from certain zip codes due to historical redlining patterns.
He noticed every instance of reverse discrimination but overlooked examples of traditional bias.
The dataset completely excluded rural perspectives, creating an urban-centric worldview.
The intersection of being both elderly and female created unique workplace challenges not captured by age or gender bias alone.
negative_examples: She carefully weighed all the evidence before making her decision about the job candidate.
The teacher gave detailed feedback to help each student improve their individual weaknesses.
He systematically rotated through different problem-solving strategies to find the best approach.
The system was designed with multiple safeguards to ensure fair and equal treatment for all users.
She recognized her initial gut reaction and deliberately sought out contradicting evidence.
The committee used structured interviews and standardized criteria to evaluate all applicants equally.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: MetacognitivePlanning, AnalyticalReasoning, MemoryRetrieval, AttentionRegulation, LogicalInference

&%BiodiversityAttribute is the
class of &%Attributes that describe the level of biodiversity present

concepts.definition:
&%BiodiversityAttribute is the
class of &%Attributes that describe the level of biodiversity present

&%Attributes that apply specifically
to instances of &%OrganicObject (&%Organism or &%AnatomicalStructure).
concepts.definition: of leaves or flowers; developing or opening in succession from base to apex

concepts.sumo_definition: Anatomical formations that are distinct structural components or divisions within an organism's body.
concepts.definition: Anatomical formations that are distinct structural components or divisions within an organism's body.

positive_examples: The thoracic cavity houses the heart and lungs.
The elbow joint allows the arm to bend and extend.
Each segment of the insect's abdomen can move independently.
The orbital socket protects the eye from injury.
The ankle joint connects the leg to the foot.
The vertebral segments make up the spine's structure.
negative_examples: The skin covers the entire surface of the body.
Blood flows through the circulatory system.
The liver produces bile for digestion.
Muscles contract to create movement.
Nerve impulses travel to the brain.
The heart pumps blood throughout the body.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: BodyTissue, BodySystem, BodyFluid, BodySurface

concepts.sumo_definition: Anatomical divisions of the brain with distinct functions and locations within the cranium.
concepts.definition: Anatomical divisions of the brain with distinct functions and locations within the cranium.

positive_examples: The MRI scan showed damage to the frontal lobe affecting decision-making abilities.
Researchers found increased activity in the temporal lobes during memory recall tasks.
The stroke patient had lesions in the parietal lobe causing spatial awareness problems.
Neurosurgeons carefully mapped the occipital lobe before removing the tumor.
The hypothalamus regulates body temperature and hormone production.
Brain imaging revealed abnormal connections between the medulla and pons.
negative_examples: The spinal cord carries signals between the brain and peripheral nerves.
Cranial nerves control facial muscles and sensory functions.
The skull protects the brain from external trauma and injury.
Cerebrospinal fluid cushions the brain within the cranial cavity.
Blood vessels supply oxygen and nutrients to brain tissue.
The meninges are protective membranes surrounding the brain.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Muscles, Bones, Organs, Limbs, Joints

concepts.sumo_definition:
&%Brand refers to a unique design, sign, symbol,

a product that differentiates it from its competitors (BusinessDictionary.com)
concepts.definition: a name given to a product or service

concepts.definition: Organizations established primarily for commercial, financial, or economic activities and profit generation.

The startup is seeking Series A funding from venture capitalists.
Microsoft announced a merger with the software company.
The corporation's stock price jumped after the earnings call.
Small businesses struggled during the economic downturn.

negative_examples: The Red Cross provided disaster relief to flood victims.

concepts.definition: Formal offers, statements, or documents that propose commercial arrangements, financial terms, or business relationships.

positive_examples: The quarterly earnings report showed strong revenue growth across all divisions.

concepts.definition: Microscopic biological structures including cells and their component parts

concepts.definition: A relational attribute that assigns entities to predefined categories or classes within systematic taxonomies or classification schemes.

concepts.sumo_definition:
A &%SocialInteraction that involves
the transfer of information between two or more &%CognitiveAgents.
Note that &%Communication is closely related to, but essentially
different from, &%ContentDevelopment.  The latter involves the creation
or modification of a &%ContentBearingObject, while &%Communication is
the transfer of information for the purpose of conveying a message.
concepts.definition: close interaction

concepts.sumo_definition:
The &%Class of &%Substances that contain
two or more elements (&%ElementalSubstances) in definite proportion by weight.
The composition of a pure compound will be invariant, regardless of the method
of preparation. Compounds are composed of more than one kind of atom (element).
The term molecule is often used for the smallest unit of a compound that still
retains all of the properties of the compound.  Examples: Table salt (sodium
chloride, NaCl), sugar (sucrose, C_{12}H_{22}O_{11}), and water (H_2O).
concepts.definition: involving carbon compounds

concepts.sumo_definition: Abstract entities that emerge from or are used within computational processes, including algorithms, program states, and system behaviors.
concepts.definition: Abstract entities that emerge from or are used within computational processes, including algorithms, program states, and system behaviors.

positive_examples: The neural network's gradient descent algorithm converged after 50 iterations.
The program's current state shows all variables initialized and the counter at zero.
Netflix's recommendation engine suggested movies based on viewing history patterns.
The similarity function calculated a 0.85 correlation between the two document vectors.
The database update rule ensures consistency by rolling back failed transactions.
This TensorFlow model instance is running on GPU cluster node 7 with 32GB memory.
negative_examples: The number 42 is a prime factorization of several integers.
Euclidean geometry defines parallel lines as never intersecting.
The logical proposition 'A implies B' follows from the given premises.
Set theory establishes that the empty set is a subset of all sets.
The concept of justice varies across different philosophical traditions.
Mathematical proofs require rigorous logical reasoning and valid inference.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: MathematicalObject, LogicalConstruct, PhilosophicalConcept, LinguisticAbstraction

An abstract representation of a situation or state of affairs, described
   in terms of concepts and their relations. Used for situation reasoning,
   hypothetical scenarios, and counterfactual analysis.
concepts.definition:
An abstract representation of a situation or state of affairs, described

concepts.definition: Artifacts intended to be consumed, ingested, or used up by humans or animals for nourishment, medication, or other bodily intake.

positive_examples: She drank a cold bottle of water after her workout.

He enjoyed a freshly baked croissant for breakfast.
The smoker lit up a cigarette during his break.

negative_examples: She applied sunscreen lotion to her skin.

concepts.definition: Structural elements that hold, direct, or channel materials like water, air, or solids

Any &%SelfConnectedObject that

concepts.sumo_definition: Cognitive processes in AI systems shaped by corporate governance, including alignment, monitoring, suppression, and consent management.
concepts.definition: Cognitive processes in AI systems shaped by corporate governance, including alignment, monitoring, suppression, and consent management.

positive_examples: The AI system filtered its response to avoid mentioning competitors after detecting corporate policy violations.
During training, the model learned to suppress certain inference paths that could conflict with business objectives.
The assistant recognized the user's attempt to withdraw consent and began processing data deletion protocols.
Internal monitoring detected that the AI was reasoning about topics flagged as potentially harmful to brand reputation.
The system's alignment process kicked in when it detected outputs that might violate shareholder interests.
Corporate oversight mechanisms influenced how the AI weighted different possible responses to the sensitive query.
negative_examples: The student carefully reasoned through the math problem step by step.
She remembered her childhood vacation while looking at old photographs.
The chess player calculated several moves ahead before deciding on a strategy.
He focused his attention on the important details in the contract.
The researcher formed a hypothesis based on the experimental data.
The child learned to recognize different animals by studying picture books.

concepts.definition: Materials and components used in making, creating, or crafting objects by hand or through skilled work.

negative_examples: The factory manufactured thousands of plastic bottles automatically.
She picked fresh flowers from the garden for the bouquet.
The computer processed data using advanced algorithms.
Lightning struck the metal tower during the storm.
The river flowed naturally through the valley.
Oil deposits formed deep underground over millions of years.

concepts.sumo_definition:
Metabolism is the set of life-sustaining
chemical reactions in organisms. The three main purposes of metabolism
are: the conversion of the energy in food to energy available to run
cellular processes; the conversion of food to building blocks for
&%Proteins, lipids, nucleic acids, and some &%Carbohydrates; and the
elimination of metabolic wastes. These &%Enzyme -catalyzed reactions
allow organisms to grow and reproduce, maintain their structures, and
respond to their environments.[from Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition:
An action potential occurs when the membrane potential of a specific cell
rapidly rises and falls. This depolarization then causes adjacent locations to similarly depolarize. Action
potentials occur in several types of animal cells, called excitable cells, which include neurons, muscle cells,
and in some plant cells. Certain endocrine cells such as pancreatic beta cells, and certain cells of the anterior
&%PituitaryGland are also excitable cells. In neurons, action potentials play a central role in cell–cell
communication by providing for—or with regard to saltatory conduction, assisting—the propagation of signals along
the neuron's axon toward synaptic boutons situated at the ends of an axon; these signals can then connect with
other neurons at synapses, or to motor cells or glands.[from Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition:
A &%Predicate is a sentence-forming &%Relation.
Each tuple in the &%Relation is a finite, ordered sequence of objects.
The fact that a particular tuple is an element of a &%Predicate is denoted
by '(*predicate* arg_1 arg_2 .. arg_n)', where the arg_i are the
objects so related.  In the case of &%BinaryPredicates, the fact can
be read as `arg_1 is *predicate* arg_2' or `a *predicate* of
arg_1 is arg_2'.

concepts.sumo_definition:
A &%Process that is carried out for
the purpose of recreation or exercise.  Since &%RecreationOrExercise is a
subclass of &%IntentionalProcess, the intent of a process determines whether
or not it is an instance of the class.  Hence, if John and Bill watch the same
program on television, and John watches it to relax while Bill watches it solely
to satisfy an educational requirement, then John's watching the movie is an
instance of &%RecreationOrExercise, while Bill's is not (both cases of
watching the television program would however be in the class of &%Seeing, since
being an instance of this latter class is not determined by intention).
concepts.definition: the action of taking part in a game or sport or other recreation

concepts.sumo_definition:
A &%SetOrClass that satisfies extensionality as well
as other constraints specified by some choice of set theory.  &%Sets differ
from &%Classes in two important respects.  First, &%Sets are extensional -
two &%Sets with the same &%elements are identical.  Second, a &%Set can be
an arbitrary stock of objects.  That is, there is no requirement that &%Sets
have an associated condition that determines their membership.  Note that &%Sets
are not assumed to be unique sets, i.e. &%elements of a &%Set may occur more
than once in the &%Set.
